Sincerely,

From: Cathy Marcum <marcumcm@appstate.edu> 
Sent: Saturday, April 13, 2019 4:14 PM
To: Mazza-Paquette, Melissa <Melissa.Mazza-Paquette@vermont.gov>
Subject: Request for Contact Information

Dear Melissa:

Hello and I hope the email finds you well!  My name is Dr. Cathy Marcum and I am an associate professor of Justice Studies at Appalachian State University in Boone, NC.  My colleague, Dr. George Higgins of the University of Louisville, and I are currently doing research on the management of nonconsensual pornography cases by courts in the United States.  Dr. Higgins and I have an extensive history of publications in the cybercrime and victimization fields, as well as law enforcement response to these crimes (I am happy to send you a CV if you would like to see further information).  Our current project involves surveying district attorneys and chief prosecuting attorneys from every state to investigate their experiences with these cases, management, and outcomes.

Does your agency have an electronic or paper document available that has the contact information for these individuals for the state of Vermont?  If so, could we have access to this document?

Please let me know if you have any questions regarding the study or need any other information.  Thank you in advance for your help!

Sincerely,
Cathy Marcum

I have contracted with the Vermont Public Health Association to survey Vermont’s rural and critical care hospitals on their readiness to transition to a value-based system of care.  VtPHA received the contract from the Office of Rural Health and Primary Care at VDH. We are dovetailing this work with a parallel process that will assess the progress of the state’s HSAs to become Accountable Communities for Health.  Heidi Klein is overseeing the ACH part of the work.  
 
In preparing for the work, I reviewed materials related to the GMCB’s April 3 meeting at which you led a panel and Eric Shell presented The New Future of Rural Healthcare, Strategies for Success.  John Olson recalls that Shell provided you with a document related to “best practices” which – I gather – takes a deeper dive into some of what he presented in his PowerPoint.  Is that something you can share with me?
Also, is there an attendance list of everyone who attended the meeting?  The minutes include GMCB attendees, panelists, and people who spoke during the public comment.

Transgender Law Center hereby requests copies of the public records described below, which concern the treatment of transgender and gender-nonconforming people in custody. 
 
Please provide a copy of current Department policies and guidance, including regulations and memos, regarding: 
 a. Transportation, temporary holding, classification, and housing of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) inmates (including the most up-to-date version of 432.01 or any other responsive policies); b. Provision of appropriate medical care related to gender transition, including hormone replacement therapy and any medically necessary surgeries related to gender transition (including but not limited to vaginoplasty, orchiectomy, penectomy, clitoroplasty, labioplasty, vulvoplasty, augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization, mastectomy, reduction mammoplasty, hysterectomy, salpingooophorectomy, vaginectomy, metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, urethroplasty, scrotoplasty, placement of testicular prostheses, placement of erectile prostheses, and facial masculinization); c. Provision of appropriate undergarments (e.g., bras for transgender women; boxers, compression tops, and/or binders for transgender men);  d. Access to state-issued and commissary items (e.g. clothing, grooming, hygiene items, etc.) that may differ based on gender/sex and/or the designation of the institution where transgender people may be housed (and, in particular, commissary items available to transgender women held in men’s facilities and transgender men held in women’s facilities) (including the most up-to-date version of 432.01 or any other responsive policies);  e. Regulations surrounding hairstyle and grooming for transgender women held in men’s facilities and transgender men held in women’s facilities; f. Placement of incarcerated people in administrative segregation of any kind (either as a disciplinary measure or for the person’s protection), and access to work programs, education and training programs, and rehabilitation programs for incarcerated people held in protective or segregated custody (including the most up-to-date version of 410.06 or any other responsive policies); g. Prevention of sexual assault and harassment, response to alleged incidents of sexual assault and harassment, and any other policies intended to bring the Department into compliance with the Prison Rape Elimination Act (including the most up-to-date version of 409.09 or any other responsive policies); h. Any searches of the bodies of incarcerated people (including any guidance 

 
 
 
 
determining which gender(s) of staff may conduct searches on given populations of incarcerated people, including but not limited to incarcerated transgender people) (including the most up-to-date version of 432.01 or any other responsive policies);  i. Access to privacy while in showers for transgender people (e.g. separate shower times, partitions) (including the most up-to-date version of 432.01 or any other responsive policies); j. Recognition of chosen names and genders and/or legal name and gender changes, including any policies relating to which names, pronouns, and honorifics institution staff are to use to address or refer to incarcerated people, and under what circumstances institutions are to update incarcerated people’s records and identification;  k. Any and all policies related to sending and receiving mail, including legal mail; l. The means by which incarcerated people may submit grievances and institution staff’s obligations to respond to those grievances (including the most up-to-date version of 320.01 or any other responsive policies); m. The rights of incarcerated people to marry and the circumstances under which they may marry (including the most up-to-date version of 310 or any other responsive policies); n. Any rights specifically pertaining to incarcerated women. 
 
 
We also request copies of any policies containing the following search terms: “transgender”, “transsexual”, “trans”, “intersex”, “nonbinary”, “gender nonconforming”, “gender dysphoria”, or “gender identity disorder”.

I'm guessing that the 2005 order applies only to Consolidated as the dominant ILEC  here in Vermont. Don't VTel, Waitsfield/Champlain, TDS, Otelco, Level3/CenturyLink, Franklin, etc. lease dark fiber to competitors upon request?

This prompts me to inquire of you for copies of records transferred from the VTA to the Department, specifically the VTA's agreement/contract with Sovernet when funding/building the fiber rings with ARRA/BTOP funding.

As I understand it, there was a provision in the Sovernet agreement or the enabling legislation which allowed Sovernet to not be required to unbundle dark fiber for lease to competitors when it was determined that such leasing would "undermine its business case."

Do you have documentation of any challenges to SoverNet invoking that provision or subsequent calculations of the "business case" test completed or revisited since Oak Hill Capital Partners acquired SoverNet and FirstLight or the recent Antin Infrastructure Partners acquisition of both?

Are there any documents in the Department's files detailing recommended CPG transfer conditions or other possible stipulated conditions that could or should be requested/demanded  as part of the PUC's approval of  either of the acquisitions? What public benefit does that State retain in consideration of the $33M+ investment in SoverNer fiber?

I believe many of the fiber service drops SoverNet  installed for the Community Anchor Institutions include six or eight fiber strands. Does the State/VTA retain the right to access or utilize those additional fibers at non-discriminatory rates were a competing fiber carrier such a CVFiber to offer service to the Kellogg Hubbard Library or the Twin Valley High School? Any pertinent documents are requested and would be appreciated.

Might these open access to dark fiber issues be addressed in the next Draft of the Telecom Plan? A dark fiber rulemaking or rate case?

I also learned today that the PUC staff is not aware of any records in their possession that detail which ILEC remotes are still not protected by diverse routes connecting them to their host switches. This is urgently important in light of the isolations issue and the pending NG911 RFP and proposed contract. Do you have any of the information that I requested from the PUC? If so, I request a copy.

Description:
From: Robert <robert.butani@gmail.com> 
Sent: Thursday, July 25, 2019 11:14 PM
Dear Commissioner Boedecker; 
We have reviewed the July 24 and July 25, 2019 postings to the ENB site.  Thank you.   
By email to the State dated April 3, 2019 (attached) the Permittee’s agent stated that “I believe this design change should alleviate many of the public questions, which were submitted …”
-	For your convenience I have attached the Public’s comments to this project.
The Permittee’s agent asked the State for guidance as to whether to respond to the public’s questions and/or speak to any of the public’s concerns.   
We have not located the Permittee’s response addressing the public’s concerns.   This leads us to question whether the State responded to the Permittee’s agent’s request for guidance in responding to the public’s concerns. 
Have either you or your staff instructed, recommended, suggested and/or otherwise directed the Permittee to respond to our concerns?  If yes, please provide details.
Additionally, 
For the period 2019 to present, please provide all documents and records that have not been posted to the ENB site including correspondence sent and received between the State and the Permittee, his agents and his representatives. 
The request for records is made pursuant to  1 V.S.A. § 317 .  
Thank you for your attention to this matter.
Regards,
Bob Butani

Hi Jeff, Eric, Shawn and Bryn: I’m writing to confirm my understanding, based on my phone calls with Bryn Oakleaf [VTDEC Watershed Division, Permits & Compliance Supervisor] on Feb. 6, 2019 regarding the water withdrawal from two streams in southwest Shoreham by the Hescock Farm [also called Elysian Fields Dairy Farm]. Please confirm the following:
1.       Neither the Hescocks nor their environmental consultant Matt Montgomery [Vermont Compliance Monitoring] have been issued a water withdrawal permit to take water from streams or Lake Champlain on or off their property in Shoreham, Vermont.
2.       Neither the Hescocks nor their consultant have applied for a water withdrawal permit.
3.       Neither the Hescocks nor their consultant have contacted you or other VTDEC personnel who deal with water withdrawals from streams, requesting a “sign-off” or other information regarding the existing or proposed water withdrawals from streams in Shoreham, or from Lake Champlain adjacent to Shoreham.

Please send copies of any correspondence [electronic copies, sent via email would be fine] that you have had with the Hescocks or their consultants regarding water withdrawals from streams or Lake Champlain.

I left phone messages for both Jeff and Eric on Feb. 6, 2019 and have not received replies to this date.
If I don’t receive an email or phone reply to this email, I will assume that my points above are correct.

I copied Shawn Good [VT Fish & Wildlife] on this email because he is aware of the water withdrawals, and has corresponded or spoken with various DEC personnel, Mr. Hescock, Matt Montgomery and Dori Barton about this situation.

I also copied this email to Mike Adams, USACOE. I spoke with him on the phone on Feb. 5, 2019 about the Hescock Farm water withdrawals. He said he is aware of the Hescock Farm, and he has on his agenda in the next couple of weeks to take his first step, which is to determine whether there is federal jurisdiction over these water withdrawals.

From: Walker, Mark <mark.walker@nytimes.com> 
Sent: Wednesday, September 25, 2019 12:10 PM
To: Mazza-Paquette, Melissa <Melissa.Mazza-Paquette@vermont.gov>
Subject: Public Records request

Good morning,

I hope this finds you well. My name is Mark Walker, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.


Under the Vermont Public Records Law, §315 et seq., I am requesting an opportunity to inspect copies of public records:

I would like to request a copy of correspondence from outside parties with state officials as the state prepared in 2018 to submit a proposal to Treasury nominating census tracks that would be designated as Opportunity Zones. This would include all such correspondence from January 2018 through June 2019.

This request is only related to the following census tracts: 

50017959400
50027966700

This would not include correspondence only among state officials. Just emails received by these officials from outside parties related to these tracts as they were considered for possible inclusion in the Opportunity Zones plan and after designation. Please also include any other emails even if they do not have these tract numbers in them, but are part of the discussion.

Please provide copies of all emails received by or sent to outside parties by officials from the who were involved in the nomination process including state or county or other local officials and any private parties. 

I respectfully request that you waive all fees in connection with this request as provided by 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).  FOIA was designed to provide citizens a broad right to access government records. FOIA’s basic purpose is to “open agency action to the light of public scrutiny,” with a focus on the public’s “right to be informed about what their government is up to.” U.S. Dep’t of Justice v. Reporters Comm. For Freedom of Press, 489 U.S. 749, 773–74 (1989) (internal quotation and citations omitted). In order to provide public access to this information, FOIA’s fee waiver provision requires “[d]ocuments shall be furnished without any charge or at a [reduced] charge . . . disclosure of the information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester.”  5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii).

The law requires a response to this request within 2 days, or within 10 days for extraordinary circumstances.  If you expect a significant delay in fulfilling this request, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.


Thank you for considering my request.

Please call me if this request is not clear. I can be reached at 202 862 0414.
-- 
Mark Walker

To whom it may concern,

Dear Melissa,

Under the Freedom of Information Act and Vermont Public Records Law, I am requesting an opportunity to inspect and obtain copies of all public records that relate to the following categories of information:

I request all public records that relate to bids and award for State of Vermont Request for Proposal eProcurement Solution and Implementation Services, including but not limited to, copies of all of the bidder’s proposal documents and related attachments as well as the State’s documents relating to the award and decision for award. 

If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $250.00.  I would request that the information be provided either by email (michelle.fombelle@proactis.com) or alternatively in hard copy mailed to Michelle Fombelle, Marketing Coordinator, Proactis, 2111 E. Highland Ave, Suite B-375, Phoenix, Arizona 85016 by overnight mail. We will be happy to pay all associated costs. 

I would request a prompt response to this request. If you expect a significant delay in responding to or in fulfilling this request, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records. 

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures to me under the law. 

I sincerely appreciate your help in this matter. Thank you for considering my request. If you need any additional information or have any questions or comments, please don’t hesitate to contact me by email at michelle.fombelle@proactis.com or by phone at 602-445-2288. 

Sincerely,
Michelle Fombelle

Subject: Obtaining a birth record for 1790-1810

Good Morning,
I am in the process of Applying for the Mayflower Society and need a copy of my 2nd great Grandfather John Nelson's birth record. 

His parents are Artemissa Chamberlain born in  Thetford, VT (Apr 20, 1774) and Charles Campbell Nelson born in Woodstock, Windham, Connecticut (March 1768). John's parents were married in Thetford, March 4, 1790. 

I believe John was born around 1802 in Thetford or a neighboring town. I have contacted Thetford town clerk and they have not been able to locate his birth record. 

How would I go about requesting a search  for his birth record in the state of Vermont to cover the span of 1790 to 1810? I only need an informational copy of his birth record not a certified copy.

Thank you,
Annette Weiskircher

Putney VT

Dear Commissioner Boedecker; 

Yesterday, during a review of the ACT 250 website, I learned of Environmental Notice Bulletins (“ENB”) issued by your office to the Applicant (attached).   The ENBs are dated November 6 and November 8, 2019.  
I will note for the record that as an abutter to this project and one who has signed up to receive email notifications from your office, I have not received these ENB’s.   
Moreover I am not aware that any of my neighbors whose properties adjoin the project site or who live downstream from the discharge waters have received these ENB notices.  
 
This is very concerning to me.  

Please provide a specific response to each of the following requests:

-	Please explain why only the Applicant has been provided with current ENB notices.
-	Please explain why the applicable property owner and residents are similarly excluded form receiving the latest notices.
-	Were are the Applicant’s response to the public comments submitted on August 8, 2019? 

Pursuant to 1 V.S.A. § 317   please provide all documents and records that have not been posted to any ENB site including correspondence, electronic and otherwise,  sent and received between the State and the Permittee, Permittee’s agents and his representatives. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Bob

Bob Butani
31 Fletcher Place
Burlington, VT 05401

Thank you very much for the information you sent me on December 20. However, I found that it did not fully answer my questions. 

Clearly, for Medicare, the GMCB, CMS and OCV do not use the terminology "expected total cost of care". Instead a "benchmark" is developed and reviewed and agreed to by CMS for the fiscal year. However, it really is not clear how that benchmark is arrived at. I understand that for 2018 it was developed from the 2017 base year, with a trend, and estimates for attrition. However, nowhere in the document does it describe how the trend is developed or agreed upon. I would think this is crucial and would like to understand how it is derived. 

Also, the information I have shows that ACO was over budget in 2017 by $4.5 million. But in 2018, the benchmark number you supplied is substantially lower than 2017. What is the explanation?

In addition, clearly the $7.7 million for the Blueprint and SASH are agreed to up front, in 2018 and now in 2019 for 2020.How is it possible to agreed on $7.7 million in "savings" before the fiscal year even begins? It appears from what you supplied that this was agreed to in developing the benchmark for 2018. How is that "savings"?.

Furthermore, I think the GMCB and OCV should be prepared to explain why savings occurred, in other words, what clinical or other interventions resulted in reduced spending in what expenditure areas. This is crucial to understand the success of the ACO. 

I would appreciate a follow up to your offer to meet with me. I don't think any of the documents available to date answer these questions, which I consider essential to understanding where savings come from and how they are derived. 

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and I look forward to hearing from you. 

Patrick Flood

https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/ap-coordinators/exam-ordering-fees/exam-fees/federal-state-assistance/2018-19-details-by-state  
 
In this link it states a low SES student would pay $53 total for an AP exam (unless a particular school decides to subsidize further, the way I understand). I'm interested this number as far back as 2000. If there were no subsidies provided during certain years, I'm also interested in that information. So to make sure I'm clear, I'd like to know the $53 equivalent price for each year 2000-present. Or equivalently how much Vermont was willing to subsidize (in lieu of total price students are expected to pay which necessitates knowing College Board's subsidy price). 
 
Finally, I know some of these funds were earmarked specifically for the purpose of subsidizing AP exams. However, I was wondering if in general any other funding that also goes toward improving AP access for low-income students was granted in the same years as changes in subsidies. Basically, I would like to know if funding changes in subsidies are correlated in any way with other funding changes for AP courses in general. I know this might be out of the scope of your position, but if you could send me along, that would be great too.

Original response sent 10/3/19: 
Communications between the Attorney General’s Office and Department for Children and Families staff is confidential per attorney/client privilege. This information is exempt from public disclosure via 1 VSA §317 (c)(1).

Your response to the original response sent 10/4/19:
Please confirm that there are no communications that do not relate to legal representation. Our understanding from the Attorney General is that the Attorney General’s Office performs many services and conducts oversight beyond active legal representation (and this is an operational function of government, not advice). Please let us know if it is the DCF’s position that there is no such scope outside of privileged legal representation.

Final DCF response:
There is no other independent oversight of DCF by the AGO. They serve as DCF’s attorneys in litigation in state and federal court, per statute. The FSD AAGs provide regular legal advice to FSD, their client. Those communications are privileged.

On behalf of Protect Our Wildlife VT, we are requesting all records, as defined by the Public Records Act, pertaining to the Feb. 29, 2020 vacancies on the Fish & Wildlife Board. Excepted from this request are any records previously provided.

We'd like to request all public records, as defined by the PRA, related to incidents of capture (or capture and release), injury, or death of non-targeted or incidentally trapped species of wild and domestic animals as a result of trapping activities of any type including but not limited to "nuisance" trapping activities. We request all records from January 30, 2019 through current date. This request specifically includes:
1. All records documenting and/or discussing the capture (or capture and release), injury, or death of Canada lynx, or any other federally protected species under the Endangered Species Act, 16 U.S.C. § 1531, as the result of trapping activities in the State of Vermont.
2.  All records documenting and/or discussing the capture (or capture and release), injury, or death of any wildlife species protected under the Vermont Endangered and Threatened Species List, 10 V.S.A § 5402, as the result of trapping activities in the State of Vermont.
3.  All records documenting and/or discussing the capture (or capture and release), injury, or death of any non-targeted or incidental take of wildlife as the result of trapping activities in the State of Vermont, not included in above paragraphs.
4.  All records documenting or discussing the capture (or capture and release), injury, death of any domesticated animal whether tame or feral, including but not limited to dogs, cats and farmed animals, as the result of trapping activities in the State of Vermont. As you know, the law now requires trappers to report when they trap a dog or cat.
5.  All records documenting or discussing the capture (and/or capture and release), injury, or death of any domesticated animal or wildlife of any species as a result of activities performed under 10 V.S.A. § 4828.
Trapping is a matter of public interest to our supporters and unfortunately, the Department publishes no data on trapped animals, either wild or domestic.

Civil rights agency personnel;

I am conducting research for Policy Matters Ohio, a non-partisan policy research institute. 

We are trying to assess how Ohio’s state-level capacity to address civil rights violations compares to other states. I would be grateful if you could answer the following questions. If you can not answer all of them, I’d be grateful if you answered the ones that you can answer easily: 
•	How many inspectors and or employees you currently employ?
•	How many complaints did you handle in 2017? In 2018? 
•	Are the only state-level agency in your state doing this work?
•	Do you receive state funding in addition to federal funding? If so, can you provide the amount you received in 2017 and 2018?
•	Finally, does your state extend protection beyond federally protected status of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, age or disability? 
o	If so, which of the following are protected?: 
	pregnancy status, 
	genetic information, 
	marital status, 
	sexual orientation, 
	gender identity and expression, 
	AIDS/HIV status, 
	medical condition, 
	political affiliation, 
	military or veteran status, 
	status as a victim of domestic violence, assault or stalking
•	Are there other protected status categories in your state not listed above? If so, please list:

I would greatly appreciate your cooperation and hope to hear from you soon.

Thanks,
Zane Steiber

Description:
Good Morning.

I left a voice mail this morning asking for some further assistance with a FOIA matter.  We've made three (3) requests to the Town of Norwich requesting information from:

1.   Town Manager - Herb Durfee (hdurfee@norwich.vt.us) 
2.   Town Planning and Zoning Director - Rod Francis (rfrancis@norwich.vt.us) 
2.   Police Department - Chief Jennifer Frank (jennifer.frank@vermont.gov)
3.   Committees and committee members - various

We are attempting to confirm that the Town and its various departments have fulfilled the request(s) by checking the VT.Gov server and computer system to ensure that the Town of Norwich has been truthful and forthcoming in their responses.

How do we make a request for the data (emails) on the Vermont State server (computer storage)?

Thank you

Dear Mr. Tim Cassese:
Hello. My name is Eric Wienckowski and I am a former graduate student at the Limnological Research Center of the University
of Minnesota. I am conducting a research project on the history of bathymetric surveys in natural lakes for use as a reference
in lake sedimentation and coring studies.
During the course of my research, I have come across references to your bathymetric surveys on some lakes in Vermont. If it
isn't too much trouble, I would be interested in the following pieces of information concerning them:
1) Year conducted
2) Number of transects/soundings
3) Maximum depth recorded
4) Elevation of lake at time of survey
5) Any assistants on the surveys
I would also be interested in obtaining, if possible, datasets of the X,Y,Z sounding data.
Any information that you may be able to provide me with would be greatly appreciated. Thank you for your time.
Regards,
Eric Wienckowski

Hi Marcella,
Thank you for the guidance.
Pursuant to the access to public records law, I'm looking for agency records from this year and last concerning water quality issues
related to dairy farms and/or enforcement actions in 2018 and 2019 against dairy farms.
As an example, the note below from Laura DiPietro at the Agency of Agriculture, Food and Markets mentions one complaint filed
this year against a farm, and that this complaint was deemed to be a direct discharge and referred to ANR. So I'm looking for this
enforcement action, related documents, and any agency records from ANR regarding dairy farms and water quality concerns in
2018 and 2019.
In addition, I am requesting agency records related to the Vorsterveld Farm in Ferrisburgh and Panton. I know the agency has
already released documents to attorney Rob Woolmington related to this farm, so hopefully these records have already been
compiled. I am specifically interested in how complaints that the farm violated wetlands regulations, or discharged waste directly
into waterways, were addressed or resolved.
I can be reached at 223-4685 or 802 373-6615 if you have any questions.
Thanks very much,
John

Dear Marcella,
I’d like to request a copy of the Vermont Toxic Discharge Control Strategy from 1994. It is referenced in section 29A‐303, Part (7) (D) of the current version of the Vermont Water Quality Standards, pasted below. VWQS § 29A‐303, Part (7)(D): “Where numeric criteria for a toxic substance are not established by these rules, the Secretary may establish such criteria consistent with subsection (7) of this section, based on the procedures set forth in the Vermont Toxic Discharge Control Strategy (1994).”
Thank you,
Elena

Good Afternoon Marcella,
Our firm is performing an Environmental Assessment of a real property located within the jurisdiction of the Vermont DEP. Under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL), I am writing to request that a review be made of northern Vermont department records which are relevant to the purpose of this Environmental Assessment. Please forward this FOIL request to the following VT DEP departments for review of department records, if available with regard to the subject site or facility(ies) (referenced below.)
1) Regulatory Services - permits and registrations (active and inactive).
2) Environmental Enforcement - complaint/notice of violation files, legal proceedings.
3) Solid and Hazardous Waste - site files for active and inactive sites associated with the subject address.
4) Petroleum Bulk Storage - tank closure reports, registered facilities.
7) Spills Division - record of petroleum/chemical releases.
Site:
STREET ADDRESS: 7-8 Kali Lane and 249-250 Tomlinson Lane
MUNICIPALITY: Johnson
COUNTY: Lamoille
CURRENT OWNER: Donald Weikert
PAST Owner:
CURRENT USE: Residential Apartment Rental
PAST USE: Vacant- Woodlands
SIZE: 32 acres
Parcel No.: 183-005
If you have any questions regarding this request for information, please contact our Buffalo office at 716-845-6145. The information that you provide is greatly appreciated.

Sharon Bissell,
Good afternoon.
My name is Ralph Perkins and I live in Colchester.
The Town of Colchester has been working on a sewer project for 289 lakeshore properties along Malletts Bay. Last March the voters rejected the bond request by the select board.
I believe the grants / loans from the State are still available to them for this project if they get it past the voters this March. I am interested to see the town’s argument for public funds and how the State weighed costs and benefits before approving funds. For example, how did E coli factor into the State’s criteria to approve the grant? Other factors?
What information would I need to provide to you so that you would be able to provide me with the grant/loan approval documents? I believe the Town has been approved for both a “Clean Water State Revolving Loan” and a “Pollution Control Grant.”
Thanks&
Hope all is well,
‐Ralph P.

To Melissa Mazza-Paquette, 
I hope this finds you well. My name is Jessica Gray, and I am reaching out on behalf of PitchBook Data's research team. I am currently seeking updated quarterly performance data from your plan’s alternative asset holdings for the following date(s): 1Q2010 through the most recent available report. 
Thank you in advance for the time you take in sending me the responsive documents, and if there is another person or distribution email I should resend this to, please let me know. Below follows the formal request. 
On behalf of PitchBook Data, Inc., under Vermont Public Records Law, I request a copy of the quarterly public records from 1Q 2010 through the most recent available report for the following information, preferably in Excel or PDF format. 
1. Names and vintage years of all private equity, venture capital, mezzanine, distressed, real estate/REIT, debt and infrastructure partnerships in Vermont Pension Investment Committee's portfolio. 
2. Commitments made to each partnership. 
3. Contributions drawn down since inception. 
4. Distributions made to Vermont Pension Investment Committee to date by each individual partnership. 
5. Net Asset Value of each partnership. 
6. Internal rates of return (IRRs) for each partnership with and without the use of credit facility. Please note if the IRRs are not net. 
7. Investment multiple (TV/PI) for each individual partnership. 
8. The dollar amount of “total management fees and costs paid” for each individual partnership. 
9. Date as of which all the above data was calculated. 
10. Names of all alternative asset partnerships partially and fully sold by Vermont Pension Investment Committee, including date of sale. 
11. For each fund, please indicate whether or not the fund uses Subscription Credit Facilities. 
I also request a copy of any documents which contain some or all of the following information: 
12. Names of all hedge fund holdings (including hedge fund of funds) in Vermont Pension Investment Committee's portfolio. 
13. Month by Month Market Value for each hedge fund holding (including hedge fund of funds) since Vermont Pension Investment Committee's initial investment up to 2Q 2018. 
14. Month by Month Contributions to each hedge fund holding (including hedge fund of funds) since Vermont Pension Investment Committee's initial investment up to 2Q 2018. 
15. Month by Month Returns (net of fees) earned by Vermont Pension Investment Committee for each hedge fund holding (including hedge fund of funds) since initial investment up to 2Q 2018. 
If there are any fees for searching for, reviewing, or copying the records, please inform me before you task the request. If you deny all or any part of this request, please cite each specific exemption you think justifies your refusal to release the information and notify me of appeal procedures available under the law. 
Please do not hesitate to contact me with any questions. My full contact information is listed below, and if there is another person or distribution email I should resend this to, please let me know. 
Thank you in advance for your help on this request. 
Warm regards, 
JESSICA GRAY Dataset Lead, Limited Partners 
PitchBook | pitchbook.com | jessica.gray@pitchbook.com 
T +1 206. 823.3525 | twitter @pitchbook

Description: Names/case numbers of all employees of Chittenden Regional Correctional Facility who have been investigated by Vermont State Police since 2011.  This would include any employee who has been accused of misconduct by either an inmate or another staff member.

I am surveying multiple state agencies, cities and school districts as to their practices concerning what is commonly known as “official time” or “release time.” This is where representatives of public employee unions or labor organizations are given paid time off from their regular government duties to perform union work. For illustrative purposes, this is similar to the practice in the federal government documented here:
https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/labor-management-relations/reports-on-official-time/
 
To that end, I am asking that you provide me with documentation disclosing the following information for each and every department within your agency, and for the most recently concluded fiscal year:
-          Name of the union or unions representing employees of the department.
-          Total number of hours of official/release time permitted by the department, specified by union or bargaining unit.
-          Total cost of all official/release time for your department, including salary and all benefits.
-          The specific section in each labor agreement that allows for official/release time for each department, as well as copies of the relevant portions of those agreements. If those agreements are already available online, please direct me to the web address and the appropriate section.
-          Any reports documenting, describing or explaining the use of release time prepared for the governing body (i.e. governor, legislature) or management (i.e. agency director)
-          Any policies or practices related to the use of release time by your department.
-          The amount of the cost of release time that was paid by the union or bargaining unit, either directly or through reimbursement to your agency
 
Again for illustrative purposes, I am attempting to compile a database similar to that published by the federal Office of Personnel Management through weblink above, but focusing on state and local entities. In processing this request, it may be helpful for you to review the OPM’s format in the link, particularly the last dozen or so pages of each annual report which documents for each agency the total number of official time hours, their uses and costs in both salary and benefits. In the 2016 report, this table is found under Appendix B beginning on Page 19 of the PDF.  While I understand that you may not have an obligation to create new records, this approach may be easier for your agency than sending copies of all relevant records on which the information requested above appears.  
 
In addition, for each employee who used 500 or more hours or official/release time in the last full fiscal year, please provide the following information:
-          Employee name
-          Location (city or facility)
-          Union name
-          Job Title
-          Total number of official/release time hours used, by fiscal year, for each of the five past fiscal years
-          Annual cost in salary and benefits for official time for for each of the five past fiscal years
-          The amount of the cost of release time that was paid by the union or bargaining unit, either directly or through reimbursement to your agency
-          Any specific reports filed by the employee describing how the release time was used
 
To be clear, while this practice is generally referred to as official or release time, I am seeking this information about that or any similar practice which allows public employees to be released from their regular duties to do work for their union while drawing salary and benefits from public entities, regardless of what you may call it.

Ms. Nicolai, I am writing to you as a person listed on the Department's website as a public records officer.  I am cc'ing Attorney Beling.

The City of Montpelier, in conjunction with the Capitol Plaza, is planning a parking garage at the intersection of the Winooski River and the North Branch.  This location is subject to periodic flooding.   According to the engineering documents filed with the District Commission, the bottom two floors of the proposed parking garage site will be lower than the Base Flood Elevation. One floor will be 7.8 feet below Base Flood Elevation; the other will be 13.8 feet below Base Flood Elevation.  Dubois & King Response to Act 250 Recess Memo Flood Related Criterion 1(D), Ronald C. Lyon, February 25, 2019, p.3.  The site lies within the 100-year floodplain of the Winooski River and North Branch rivers. Base Flood Elevation refers to 100-year storms.   Although the two floors will be substantially lower (7.8 and 13.8 feet) than the 100-year storm elevation, nothing filed by the applicant addresses how frequently these floors will be flooded during 1-year, 10-year, 25-year or 50-year storms.   

According to the application documents, the parking garage is designed so that during flooding the waters of the Winooski River will flow through the two bottom levels of the parking garage.  See Dubois & King memo, above.  That is, the design of the garage will allow the river's waters to flow into the building and then back out. 

The Clean Water Act states that a "point source" is: "any discernible, confined and discrete conveyance, including but not limited to any pipe, ditch, channel, tunnel, conduit, well, discrete fissure, container, rolling stock, concentrated animal feeding operation, or vessel or other floating craft, from which pollutants are or may be discharged."  "Discharges" include "any addition of any pollutant to navigable waters from any point source." Vermont's Water Pollution Permit Regulations adopt these definitions.  The regulations and state statutes require that an individual discharge permit be obtained for any point source discharge. 

The plans for the garage include one or more discernible, confined and discrete conveyances, including but not limited to pipes, ditches, channels, conduits, wells, discrete fissures, and/or containers, that will collect waste materials from the floors of the parking garage and that will be open to the waters of the river during the expected flooding.  These include what in common parlance would be called a holding tank and/or trenches.  The waste materials are likely to include the commonly encountered components of  parking lot runoff -- lead, zinc, copper, salt, sediment, anthropogenic organic compounds, nutrients, and microbial contaminants, which can be harmful to human and aquatic life. [1]

The collection of these pollutants in pipes, ditches, channels, conduits, wells, discrete fissures, and/or containers, and then the discharge of them into the river during the expected flooding, appears to require an individual discharge permit.  The federal courts have held that runoff that is "collected or channeled by human beings" constitutes a "point source."  

I am writing, therefore, under the Public Records Act, to request copies of all documents, including memoranda and reports, and also including all communications such as letters or emails with the City, with Capitol Plaza or with any other agency or person, that pertain to: 

a) whether a point source (NPDES) permit is required or is not required for this parking garage;

b) whether a point source permit may be applied for, is being applied for, or should be applied for; or 

c) the contents or potential contents of all individual discharge permits or draft individual discharge permits.

Please let me know if this request would be unduly time-consuming or burdensome.  If so, I will try to narrow the request.  Also please let me know if the request would benefit from clarification.  Thanks.

I'd like to please request your agency's entire database on all wastewater spills or accidental releases —  in all its forms whether treated, untreated or raw sewage — from your current digital system with all dates, locations and all other column fields. If it’s necessary to limit the request to certain dates, we are requesting everything between January 1, 2004 and December 31, 2019. 
 
If the data is kept separately, I'd also like to request the agency's database on fines and any other penalties for those releases. 

For the above databases, I'd like to request any documentation, such as a data dictionary that describes the fields and how they relate to each other. 

We would need the records in an electronic format that can be imported into standard database software.

Per our data guru, examples of such formats include an Excel .xls or .xlsx file, an Access .mdb or .accdb file, a text-based delimited file such as .csv or tab-delimited .txt, a .dbf file or an SQL dump readable by standard open-source database software. (A PDF file would not comply with this request because PDF files are not readable by database software.) If this information is stored in a relational database, I request it be provided in its original relational format, not "flattened" or de-normalized.  

Here's my phone number if I can answer any questions: 386-801-5814
If there are fees associated with this request, please let me know in advance. However, we would request a waiver of any fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and would contribute significantly to the public's understanding. And, if any significant delay is expected, please let me know.    
Thanks so much in advance for your help. 

Here's an example from another state. 

Kindest regards,
Dinah Voyles Pulver

EXTERNAL SENDER: Do not open attachments or click on links unless you recognize and trust the sender.
Good morning,
My name is Finlay Buchanan-Jacobs, and I am a student at the University of Vermont.

I am emailing you to inquire about the Vermont Public Records Act, and several requests for financial documents that I have filed with the presiding officer (Gary Derr). I have, on multiple occasions, attempted to procure documents relating to the current financial state of the University of Vermont, with the intent of better understanding the need for UVM’s recent faculty time and pay cuts. I have received no response from Mr. Derr to these requests, which as I understand is a violation of state law and constitutes a misdemeanor charge. It is my hope that you can provide the documents that I have requested, or provide me further information on how to press charges against Mr. Derr, if he continues to fail to comply with state law and I am unable to attain the documents.

I understand this is a difficult time for all involved, but it frustrates me immensely that UVM is obstructing independent investigation into their finances, especially at a time when UVM intends to cut salaries of low paid employees and leave many employees below the Vermont Livable Standard while maintaining exorbitant administrative salaries.

I would greatly appreciate any further insight that you could provide on this issue.

I hope you and your family are staying safe and healthy during this difficult time.

Best Wishes,
Finlay Buchanan-Jacobs

Good Afternoon Ms. Connolly, 

I am a research assistant for Jill R. Horwitz, a Professor of Law at UCLA School of Law and a productive scholar in the fields of health policy and economics. Part of my research has included evaluating Certificate of Need laws throughout the country and understanding how they may regulate CT and MRI scanners.  

Would you have a few minutes to speak with me on the phone about Vermont's CON law? Or could you answer a few questions over email? I would be very grateful if you could provide some clarification on the following: 

1. Can you confirm that Vermont’s CON law regulates CT/MRI scanners if they cost in excess of $1.5 million (for hospitals) and $1 million (for a health care facility other than a hospital)? 

2. It is my understanding that a CON is required if a freestanding diagnostic imaging center or independent physicians group (not associated with a hospital) wanted to buy an MRI/CT scanner in excess of $1 million. Is that correct? 

3. Can you confirm when the current CON law was enacted?

Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to hearing from you soon. 

All the best,

Jason Weiss 
UCLA School of Law | J.D. Candidate | Class of 2021

Fund relationships

Secondary activity
1. Any documents pertaining to whether you have ever bought or sold any private equity, private debt, real estate or infrastructure fund interests in the secondaries market. (i.e. have you bought or sold anything in the secondaries market) 2. If so, any documents pertaining to the price in relation to NAV that the interest or interests we transacted at. (i.e. what was the price) 3. If so, any documents pertaining to the identity of the counter-party with whom the interest(s) were transacted (i.e. who was the buyer or seller).
4. If so, any documents pertaining to the identity of any intermediary involved in the process.
5. If so, any documents pertaining to any fees paid to any intermediaries involved in the process.

I am making a PRA request based on Paragraph 12 of the Order issued by the Commission on 12/23/13 in Docket 7970, the ANGP case.  Paragraph 12 states:

12. VGS shall develop an aggressive new energy  efficiency program for its new customers in Addison County and present it to the Board for review and approval. One goal of this program shall be to invest the projected $ 200 million dollar savings into energy  efficiency transitions that will facilitate, rather than frustrate, achieving the 90% renewable   energy  goal by 2050. At a minimum, VGS needs to ensure that its proposal addresses three issues: (1) its new industrial (and residential) customers  in Addison County and the shaping of their energy  efficiency future; (2) the opportunity for savings by industrial customers  in energy  efficiency technology as they invest in conversion to natural gas  (e.g., replacing old technology with more efficient technology rather than simply converting it to natural gas) ; and (3) ensuring that the investment of VGS ratepayers in the Project results in not only reliability and greater availability of natural gas to new customers  but also greater energy  efficiency (and reduced GhG emissions)  for new and existing customers.


The word "reduced,"  as I understand it means reduced from present levels.  I can think of no other reasonable interpretation.  The reference to "GhG" refers to all greenhouse gasses, not just carbon, as is evident from the rest of the Order.  As the Department knows, carbon is just one GhG. Methane is another, far more harmful GhG. 

I have searched the public documents on the Commission's website and VGS's website and find no proposal that invests $200 million into energy efficiency or that "ensure[s] that the investment of VGS ratepayers in the Project results in not only reliability and greater availability of natural gas to new customers but also greater energy efficiency (and reduced GhG emissions) for new and existing customers." 

All that I have found that pertains to the 7970 Order is the April 2015 Order of Appointment of VGS as an EEU that states that VGS compliance with the Order in Docket 7970 will be addressed in a future proceeding.  No such future proceeding could I find.

With that as background, here are my requests.  

First, please provide me with every document that  VGS has filed with, served on or sent to the Department that pertains to any VGS proposal that ensures that investment of VGS ratepayers' funds in the ANGP is resulting in or will result in reductions of the GhG emissions of new and existing customers, and also every other communication from or to the Department about whether or how VGS is proposing to use the investment by ratepayers in the ANGP to reduce the GhG emissions of new and existing customers. 

Second, if not encompassed in the first request,  please provide me with every document that  VGS has filed with, served on or sent to the Department that pertains to how VGS is spending, has spent, or will spend the $200 million referred to in the Order, or any part of that sum, on ensuring reduced GhG emissions by new and existing customers, and also every other communication from or to the Department about this subject. 


Third, if not encompassed by the prior requests, please provide me with every document that DPS possesses that pertains to whether or not, in fact, the ANGP has resulted in, is resulting in, or will result in reduced emissions of GhG by VGS's existing or new customers.  This request pertains not to just communications with VGS but to all nonprivileged documents in DPS possession.


If these requests are confusing or would be burdensome, please let me know and I will clarify or narrow them.  Thank you.

Pursuant to Policy 4.11, I am requesting all documentation regarding the interview and hiring processes utilized in the various DOC positions to which I have applied since June of 2017.  I have attached a chronological list of those positions.  In each instance, I was an eligible and routed applicant.  As a former Appointing Authority, I know the documentation expectations covering these processes.

As identified in Policy 4.11, this documentation is best practice and critical from a legal perspective.  Hiring managers are expected to be able to show the screening factors used in choosing who to interview and who is offered the position.  There needs to be proof that the candidates were fairly and appropriately considered and that the position is offered to the candidate who possesses the best qualifications for the position.  The following records are to be retained:

-	The list of essential duties and job requirements
-	What factors were used to select the applicants to be interviewed (if not all applicants are interviewed)
-	The interview questions asked to the applicants
-	The interviewers’ observations and/or notes
-	What evaluation system was used and its results
-	A copy of the list of routed applicants and copies of candidates’ application materials

Dear Sarah and Marisa,
Greetings. I sent this email below to Alena but her automatic reply encouraged me to sent it to you in her absence.

I am writing to get some clarification on OneCare’s new primary care reimbursement plan/s for 2021. Please let me know if I have mis-stated anything. I look forward to receiving your answers to my questions.

OneCare’s Original Plan
•	Provides an upfront payment of $1.75 with the potential to rise to $4.75. 
•	After the ACO year concludes, primary care practices would receive an additional $1.50 if the ACO meets its “target” (no gains or losses) $1.75 + $1.50 = $3.25. 
•	If the ACO achieves “savings”, the primary care practices would receive an additional $1.50. ($3.25 + $1.50 = $4.75).
•	Please help me understand which categories of primary care practices are subject to OneCare’s Original Plan. All primary care participating with OneCare. CPR program is available only to independent primary care practices. Please explain what you mean in the previous sentence. Could you please define “CPR” and distinguish it from OneCare’s Original Plan.

OneCare/Healthfirst Agreement
•	Provides an upfront payment of $3.25 with $1.50 of that sum “at risk”.
•	After the ACO year concludes, “If the ACO does not meet its performance goals per payer, the practice will be required to pay back the balance owed up to $1.50.”
•	How does OCV define “performance goals”?  Financial? Quality? Other? Performance goals defined in payer contracts.
•	Does the OCV/Healthfirst agreement still allow for the “up to $4.75 PM/PM” if the ACO achieves “savings”? I see why you ask; I am not sure and need to confirm but I believe yes, the opportunity to receive the additional $1.50 up to the $4.75 would still be available. Please confirm and let me know.
•	This agreement applies only to “independent primary care practices facing economic stress”.
•	How will “economic stress” be established? Will OCV make that determination? I do not have additional information on this at this time. Based on testimony and the language I interpret this as Covid-19 hardship which affects all and allows any practice to select this option, but I would need to confirm. Please confirm and let me know.
•	Are the FQHCs, non-Healthfirst independent practices, and hospital-based primary care physicians in or out of the OCV/Healthfirst agreement? Again, I see why you ask based on the language and I need to confirm but I believe it applies to any primary care. Please confirm and let me know. You stated above: “All primary care participating with OneCare” are subject to OneCare’s Original Plan. But here you say the FQHCs, non-Healthfirst independent practices, and the hospital-based primary care physicians are subject to the OCV/Healthfirst Plan. Please clarify.   CPR program is available to any independent primary care. Please explain this last sentence.

Thank you for your assistance.

Julie Wasserman, MPH

From: Sophia Albanese <salbane@mit.edu>

Subject: FOIA Request

To whom it may concern,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Sophia Albanese and I am a research assistant at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology conducting research on telemedicine reimbursement rates in the United States. My team, led by Dr. Amar Gupta of MIT, is working in an intensive mode to collect information from FOIA surrounding the rates at which telemedicine services are being reimbursed in each state. Many state websites provide the fee schedules and CPT/HCPCS codes that are reimbursable for telemedicine, however, my team is looking for information indicating the monetary rates these services are commonly being reimbursed by national, state, and private insurers. 

This email serves as our request to receive information via FOIA about your state's reimbursement data on services for telemedicine as they compare to in-person services. The ideal form of information would provide the gross data of the reimbursement rates for services provided in-person as well as the rates of reimbursement for those same services provided via telemedicine. Please note that this request is for the actual rates these services are being reimbursed for, not the intended rate that is prescribed through state parity laws. For instance, are telemedicine services being reimbursed at the same rate, lower, or higher than in-person rates for the same services?

Thank you in advance for your time and consideration. Please contact me with any questions. If you believe my request is better served for another member of your department, I would greatly appreciate it if you would share this request with the correct individuals.

Best,
Sophia Albanese
609-775-7420

From: Stephen Whitaker <whitaker.stephen@gmail.com> 
Sent: Friday, January 11, 2019 2:29 AM
To: Young, Susanne <Susanne.Young@vermont.gov>
Cc: Hoffer, Doug <Doug.Hoffer@vermont.gov>; rbrock@leg.state.vt.us; tbriglin@leg.state.vt.us
Subject: REQUEST for E911 Gartski Review due January 9th 

via email 
cc:     State Auditor Doug Hoffer, 
        Senator Randy Brock, 
        Chairman Joint Information Technology Oversight Committee
         Representative Tim Briglin
         Chairman House Energy and Technology Committee

January 11, 2019

Ms. Susanne Young
Secretary of Administration
State of Vermont.

[Nutshell excerpt:]
"It is reckless, irresponsible and unsafe to proceed with the NG911 procurement at this time under these circumstances."

Please send me a copy of the Gartski Consulting report completed as the required Independent Expert Review which was due on January 9, 2019 on the proposed NG-911 system in accordance with the attached contract/Statement of Work which you delegated to Kristy Pirie who then provided it to me on December 5, 2018.

I call to your attention the fact that the prior Independent Review (IR) conducted in 2014 by BerryDunn of the FairPoint 911 system failed to include an analysis of the redundancy and reliability of the underlying telecommunications transport network. This is due to the E911 Board having arbitrarily narrowed the definition of the NG911 system to being just the overlay network inside the FairPoint NG911 gateway, thereby neglecting to address reliability and redundancy of the underlying transport relying on the FairPoint network elements spanning Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine! 

That enormous error and omission has resulted in recurring failures of the FairPoint 911 system and also left the State of Vermont with no ability to assess financial penalties or recover damages from FairPoint due to the Service Level Agreements not being in effect at the time. This 'accountability gap' was due to "Final Acceptance" by the E911 Board of the FairPoint system not having occurred despite being several years into the contract term. 

One significant example of unrecovered or unrecoverable costs is the extensive regulatory proceedings and hiring of experts to litigate the PUC investigations into these failures, in Dockets 8390 and 8850.

Independent Reviewer BerryDunn's  2014 IER report forewarned of some of these issues with the completed contract terms being unavailable to the reviewer and the systems fundamental reliance on the SLAs. Yet these critical red flags were ignored. 

The Public Utility Commission has Docket 8850, an open investigation into the failures of the FairPoint transport and routing network, much of which will likely be relied upon by any new NG911 vendor.  

Chronic vulnerabilities which continue to leave a number of communities periodically isolated from a FairPoint host switch and unable to complete any 911 calls whatsoever is another issue that both the PUC and the E911 Board have for years failed to address or resolve.

This accountability gap necessitates that a comprehensive network analysis be completed by a qualified telecommunications network engineer of both the next proposed NG911 system but also the underlying transport network reliability and redundancy. This long overdue task must NOW be completed in the interest of public safety. 
[SEE Transcript of October 30, 2018 E911 Board meeting on pages 13-19 regarding still unresolved isolation events blocking 911 call delivery. Filed at PUC as public comment in Docket 8850]

If Comtech or CenturyLink is the yet unidentified selected vendor now in negotiations with the E911 Board and Purchasing staff, it is noteworthy that CenturyLink years ago acquired Level3 which had itself prior acquired the Vermont fiber network assets of Hyperion/Adelphia. The Level3 network in Vermont has, to my knowledge, never before been used to support an Enhanced 911 systems and as such the importance of a complete engineering network analysis both within and beyond the 911 system boundary defined by the Enhanced 911 Board must be completed. The same required analysis of redundancy and reliability which has still not yet completed for the Consolidated network has NEVER been completed for the Level3 network in Vermont! 

These are tasks which are clearly not included in the attached Scope of Work for the proposed NG911 system Independent Review and I suspect are also far beyond the skill level of Paul Gartski as a so-called independent reviewer. 

Even were BerryDunn to be retained again for the IR with a broader Scope of Work, they would almost certainly require additional funding to retain telecom engineering expertise to complete such an extensive analysis. This would likely be beyond the arbitrary cost limitations defined by Purchasing for these statutorily required Independent Expert Reviews as are documented in the State "Purchasing Handbook".

The Enhanced 911 Board was last year forewarned that expert analysis should be retained prior to issuance of the  NG911 RFP and it was not, my advice again being simply ignored. It is reckless, irresponsible and unsafe to proceed with the NG911 procurement at this time under these circumstances.

I also hereby officially request a copy of the Statement of Qualifications for Paul Gartski to conduct IRs for the State of Vermont, specifically applicable to telephone network infrastructure engineering and NG911 systems or services.

Kind regards,

Stephen Whitaker

From: Stephen Whitaker <whitaker.stephen@gmail.com>
Sent: Wednesday, January 16, 2019 11:33:19 AM
To: Young, Susanne
Cc: Hoffer, Doug
Subject: APPEAL to the Head of the Agency 
 
via email

January 16, 2019

Ms. Susanne Young
SecAdmin
State of Vermont

 Re: Independent Review of proposed NG911 system report.

Pursuant to Vermont Access to Public Records Laws, 1 V.S.A. §§ 315 et. seq., I hereby APPEAL TO THE HEAD OF THE AGENCY the denial of access to the Independent Expert Review of the NG911 system proposal requested from you on January 11, 2019. 

The Independent Expert Review of major IT systems and services are required of your office by statute in 3 V.S.A. 2222 (g). Ms. Mazza's misdirection or attempt to restart the statutory clock for production of a public record by suggesting erroneously that ADS is responsible for these reports is clearly erroneous in that the proposed Bill attempting to make that change died in Committee last biennium.

The three business days clock has since lapsed for you to claim the need for a ten day extension or need to additional time for consultation with other agencies or the Attorney General or to complete redactions and as such the Gartski report should be made available forthwith.

 As you have provided no written response to my two recent letters to you detailing the many problems with this NG911, RFP, the procurement process, the incomplete and unapproved stipulated settlement between Consolidated Communications and the Department of Public Service and unresolved network reliability issues, I am extremely concerned that your administration intends to attempt to force this contract though the purchasing process at great risk to public safety as well as further erode the "faith and trust in government" that Governor Scott pledged to retore.

Thank you.
Stephen Whitaker
Statutory_Exemption: 1V.S.A § 317(c)(15) negotiation of contracts,1V.S.A § 317(c)(25) safety of persons and public property,1V.S.A § 317(c)(9) trade secrets

1). The complete records of all Biobase scans that were done on Little Lake - last year and any previous years of sonar scanning. We are looking for all reports and maps that can be accessed from the scan data.  Specifically we want to see the track of the boat, contour with 1 foot intervals, bottom composition, vegetation biovolume heat map, vegetation analysis report, any manual offsets or data adjustments, and whether the scan was completed in one trip or multiple trips were merged.  If multiple trips were merged, we would like to see the same information for the individual trips.  We would also like to know what the established baseline water elevation was at the time of the scan.  At this time we are not requesting the detailed data for vegetative biovolume or bottom composition, but we may want to have a look at it later.  If you want to export that data into excel and send it along, that would be fine.
2) All historical depth measurements taken on Little Lake, and the methods use to take these measurements.
3) Copies of all permits ever issued to the LSCCF
Thank you for your help with this. I’m looking forward to working together for a healthier lake.
Sincerelly,
David
